content:
Does anyone have any reading suggestions for theory on formal verification? I'm after something introductory.
Apologies if this isn't the right stream to ask in – if it isn't I'd be grateful if someone could suggest where the correct place to ask this would be.
what's your background? is there anything in specific you're interested in?

I don't really have a background in anything specific – I have some general computer science knowledge though. I'm interested in formal verification (proving that programs work as intended) of software programs – something that would allow me to understand Prusti's codebase (it's a "prototype verifier" built on Viper) would be useful.

To understand Prusti's internals a necessary step is to learn about Viper. That page links to several papers, but the tutorial is probably the best starting place. If you are looking for a broader introduction to formal software verification, I would suggest to look for lecture slides or recordings on Google. For example, this course at ETH explains how Viper is realized.
you can also look at this course from the MPRI https://www.lri.fr/~marche/MPRI-2-36-1/ for a general introduction to deductive verification
Thanks a lot for these recommendations! These look interesting. I'll have a look at the suggested courses (and search DuckDuckGo for some more).
also ask questions here!! I want to revive this channel as much as possible
I have this tab pinned so it's nearly always open for me
Thanks for the offer! I'll try and join in on the revival of the formal methods channel.
